ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: There were two course instructors, and Ben Cashore was really great, but Jan McAlpine could sometimes not respond very well to student questions. However, both instructors provided very interesting ideas, were very available to students, and gave good lectures/perspectives on the course material.

The combination of an academic and a practitioner teaching this course was incredibly valuable. This is the first course Ive taken with a practitioner and I wish all my classes could be taught in a similar fashion. I would recommend any students that have an interest in forest policy to take this course. The field trip to the UN changed my view of the institution and I really appreciated that so many negotiators sat down and talked frankly with us about their work. That experiences was invaluable.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Having two professors with different background and perspectives was really great. They showed us how people in academia have different perspectives on forest related issues from practitioners.
Knowledge of academic and practitioner is unbeatable.
overview of forest governance and experience from a practitioner
Learning from other students
The field trip to the UN, and guest lecture opportunities
The combination of practitioner and academic perspectives made this course unique, and extra valuable.

The deep-dive into international forest policy and the forest convention history was really useful. Also the weekly responses were a good space to interact with the course materials and explore the concepts in relation to our own interests.

The best aspect was being exposed to both the academic and practitioner views on forest policy. I really enjoyed that the class, which could have easily been very abstract, focused on the practical aspects of the field. Jan and Ben were fantastic and I would highly recommend that this course be taught again.
The academic-practioner teaching partnership was a very strong aspect of the course, as was our trip to the U.N.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course was full of interesting and useful information, but it could have used some more structure. It would have been helpful to have a well-articulated outline for the course at the beginning. The first segment should probably cover the theoretical underpinnings of the subject matter. The remaining segments should clearly fit into a roadmap so that it is always evident what piece of the puzzle they are filling in.

Giving feedback to students' weekly reflection paper should happen promptly. Also, assigning more articles from practitioners' point of view will be really helpful to understand the differences and find ways to fill the gaps.

Clearer class structure from the beginning. Convey concepts simply. We spent most of the class very "zoomed in"- "zoom out" every once in a while and remind us why this is important and how one thing relates too another.

INSTRUCTORS -instructors were very unorganized for the first two months of the course. lectures were disorganized, professors were late and unprepared for class, homework assignments were not readCONTENT -too much time spent on political science theory and not enough on practical applications of forest policycourse might have been useful for people doing forest governance research or setting international policy, but it was not useful for people working at the local or even the national level.course should have used more case studies and capitalized on student experiencesreadings were repetitive and limited in opinion
Providing information and class materials well enough before the class. Most of the matereals are provided in the last minuites

Course organization, clarity of topics, more time and leeway for student discussion (with out an instructor taking the discussion over again, which happened frequently when discussions occurred, instead of students being able to engage with each other, student's comments were usually immediately responded to by the professor, which I feel detracts from a desire to engage in discussion, myself). Timeliness on readings, and clearer expectations and faster feedback to weekly responses.

The class discussion often did not reflect the weekly responses. There was also some organizational issues where our responses weren't really even read until later in the course, so they were not incorporated into lecture. I think it would have been nice to have more structured discussions with more student input in shaping them.
More structure at during the first few weeks would have helped me, but this improved over the course. More student led discussions would have been useful as well.
Each class could use more structure--a short lecture followed by class discussion of readings, theories, practice, etc. would be ideal.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
lectures were poorly planned and often did not leave time for discussionlectures were often not connected with readings
it was effective!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The class helps me to have a big picture of forest related policy issues.
Forest policy is a class topic FES direly needed. Very glad it was available this semester!
forest governance is an important component of a forestry curriculum, but this course focused most time on governance theory and not on forest policy implementation
Fulfills a requirement for MF (social sciences), but is also an area that I am interested in.
This course was right up my alley, so it fit in perfectly with my interests.

Very relevant as I plan to go into international forest governance work in the future, related to international organizations and NGOs-- perspectives we got in class through Jan and our guest speakers.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: After reading the syllabus, I thought it was one of the most attractive classes that I have heard of. Looking back, it was a great choice to take this class.
See answer to Q17.
I wanted to learn history of forestry governance

It is an area that seems to fit in with my interests which are in forestry, on an international scale, and previously in undergrad I had focused on environmental policy but had little exposure to forest policy specifically. It was in line with these interests that I took the course.
It overlapped with my strong interest in forest governance and gave a political science lens to issues that were of interest to me.
I have a background in general environmental policy, but never studied forest policy.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: It was great to have the perspective of a practitioner and that of an academic presented side by side. This really provided a richer understanding of a subject matter that really occupies both spheres. I think that the benefit of this juxtaposition was impaired somewhat by strong personality, which made conversation difficult at times.
I am satisfied with this class.
Yes, and in many ways exceeded them.
as mentioned, course was too focused on governance theory and not on implementation of forest policy
Yes, it was really interesting to learn from the person who took part in making decision in the past
I'm not sure. I don't know what I expected, and I realized that I didn't know a lot about the topic going in, so it's difficult to judge what I expected versus what I learned.
Yes.
Overall, I found the course very useful and gave me context of the international spaces.

I thought I would learn about the topics we covered in greater depth, and this is what I was hoping for, coming from a forest governance background. However, it was great for what it was able to accomplish within the needs of the class (where people have varying backgrounds on the topic).

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
group work should have been a component of the classstudents suggested group consultation as part of the final project, but this did not happen
I did not participate in a work group.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Trying to be more critical with the reading that we have been taking it for granted. It is a great chance to see why things are not working well in the developing countries. Understanding the existing problems by doing readings and actively engaging discussions in the class, you will be able to find solutions for these problems.
Be prepared to read a lot.
course needs reform before it is offered again

I think this would depend on the structure of the course in the future. Since this was an experimental semester, I would expect the structure would change substantially and be a bit more organized. So if that were the case, the content would be useful to get if it aligned with your interests.
